newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: PAKISTAN VEGOIL RATES SEEN RISING ON LOCAL DEMAND.
newsitem.headline: PAKISTAN VEGOIL RATES SEEN RISING ON LOCAL DEMAND.

text.p: Pakistani vegetable oil prices are likely to rise next week on increased local demand, dealers said on Saturday.
Heavy buying by local cooking oil mills in a depressed market pushed prices up between 60 and 100 rupees ($1.47 and $2.46) on Friday, a dealer of Saulat Enterprises said.
Another factor boosting prices was a lower than expected stock position in Malaysia, which had about 805,000 tonnes of palm oil at end-July, against a forecast one million tonnes.
A third factor was monsoon rains in Pakistan which had disrupted supplies of cottonseed oil from ginneries and oil extraction units to domestic markets, the dealer said.
One importer also linked the increase to government restrictions on the misuse of an exemption from five percent income tax granted to industrial importers of palm oil.
Industrial importers had been selling tax-exempt imported palm oil -- meant exclusively for their own consumption -- on the market, said the importer, who asked not to be named.
Since this practice stopped after the government cracked down, palm oil prices had risen between 60 and 100 rupees.
RBD palm oil prices jumped to $525 per tonne C&F from $505 last week and soyoil eased slightly to $555 per tonne C&F from $560 last week, the dealer said.
Vegoil stocks fell to 130,000 tonnes, including 105,000 tonnes of RBD palm oil and olein, from 135,000 tonnes last week.
